title.narrative: BEHAVIORAL CHANGE FOR OPTIMAL NUTRITIONPRACTICES IN COMMUNITIES

description.narrative: By 2020, adolescent girls, women of childbearing age and family members, including men, and community leaders have knowledge and aptitudes that enable optimal nutrition practices., which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020 adolescent girls, women of childbearing age (especially pregnant and breastfeeding women) and their children aged 0-59 months adopt better nutrition practices and use quality nutrition-specific and sensitive services.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, adolescent girls, women of childbearing age and family members, including men, and community leaders have knowledge and aptitudes that enable optimal nutrition practices.

description.narrative: With UNICEF support, seven NGOs in 7 health regions, 2,401 villages out of 3,000 planned (80%) provided infant and young child feeding (IYCF) services. 22,579 mothers support groups met monthly with facilitation of 7,686 CBHWs and 3,181 community volunteers. 558,767 pregnant and lactating women benefited from IYCF counselling services. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of primary caregivers of children aged 0-23 months who received counselling on IYCF
Number of service delivery points (health facility or community) that provide IYCF counselling
% of childbearing women, caretakers (father, mother-in-law, grandmother), adolescent girls and community leaders who know at least 4 optimal IYCF practices
Number of pregnant and lactating women (children from 0-24 months) who received IYCF counselling services
Number of villages with community health workers trained to deliver IYCF counselling services
